intro: Gasteranthus calcaratus subsp. calcaratus, commonly known as the rock orchid, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is characterized by its unique, showy flowers that resemble small orchids, with a distinctive, inflated gaster-shaped ovary. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, thriving in cool, moist environments. Its flowers are pollinated by specific insect species, contributing to its ecological significance in its native habitat. The subspecies is notable for its ornamental value and is often cultivated in botanical gardens.
